Event description: The Surgeon performed Umbilical Hernia Repair to a Patient. The patient had recurrence of hernia afterwards (not long after the operation).

The product specialist who was present during the revision case for hernia repair, performed 18 months ago and using Proceed mesh.

The surgeon performed the case as an open repair of a large recurrent incisional hernia and found many extensive adhesions to the mesh that were not easily removed. There was also a brownish coloured substance around a small section of the mesh that may have been due to infection.
Ventral hernia repaired with Parietex Composite mesh 15x10cm. Surgeon believes that the mesh failed in the centre of the mesh and patient had a recurrence.

Patient underwent a Pelvic Prolapse repair surgery. 1.5 hrs after the procedure, the surgeon was informed that the patient was bleeding. Patient was taken to the theatre where the surgeon removed the mesh and completed the surgery by doing native tissue repair (hand sewing).

It was reported the patient was implanted with an Uphold LITE Vaginal Support System during a procedure.

Reportedly, the patient presented with mesh erosion during a follow-up appointment three months post-implantation.

The mesh was explanted.

Patient had an umbilical hernia repair. At operation, a complex collection of hernias were encountered at the umbilicus. There were true umbilical defects to the left and right of the umbilical stalk with protusion of extraperitoneal fat. In addition, there were 2 supraumbilicasl hernias of the linea alba, again with (larger) herniation of extraperitoneal fat. All defects were defined and then unitesd to create a defect of 5cm diameter. The repair was made in a tension free manner with a 10x15cm intraperitoneal composite mesh which was sutured to the defect margins and anchored with tacks at the perimeter. Patient developed discharge post op. Seroma evident and serous fluid aspirated. Presented two weeks later with granuloma tissue and signs of infection. Mesh was explanted.
Patient underwent revision surgery to repair recurrent abdominal hernia. At revision surgery it was noted that the Proceed mesh implanted 8 months previously had a 5 cm defect in the middle.
During insertion of the Anterior Mesh to the left pelvic wall, the mesh entered the bladder medial to the ureter.
Mesh used for hernia repair was removed from packaging mesh layers of patch appeared to have separated.
During Abdominal Plasty Procedure, Proceed mesh was going to be used, however, mesh adhered to bowel upon placement.

It was reported that the patient was implanted with an Uphold LITE Vaginal Support System during a vaginal mesh repair procedure via a vertical incision.

Three months post-implantation, mesh erosion was noticed at the midline. The patient returned to the Operating Room and underwent a mesh revision procedure, where mesh bits were cut away and vaginal skin was sutured to cover the exposure. Reportedly, the surgeon said [it] looked like dehiscence.

It was reported the patient was implanted with an Uphold LITE Vaginal Support System during a vaginal mesh repair procedure via a vertical incision.
Six weeks post-implantation, mesh erosion was noticed at the midline. The patient returned to the Operating Room and underwent a mesh revision procedure, where mesh bits were cut away and vaginal skin was sutured to cover the exposure. Reportedly, the surgeon said [it] looked like dehiscence.

It was reported the patient was implanted with an Uphold LITE Vaginal Support System during a vaginal mesh repair procedure via a vertical incision.
Four weeks post-implantation, mesh erosion was noticed at the midline. The patient returned to the Operating Room and underwent a mesh revision procedure, where mesh bits were cut away and vaginal skin was sutured to cover the exposure. Reportedly, the surgeon said [it] looked like dehiscence.
Following a laparoscopic hernia procedure, the patient has had an allergic reaction. The patient has been refferred to a dermatologist to determine whether they developed a reaction to this product.

It was reported that the patient had a small erosion which was trimmed. Estrogen cream was prescribed as well. Subsequently, the patient's partner complained of pain during intercourse. A small fibre was found and was trimmed, the date of the procedure was not provided. Estrogen Cream was continued. Additionally, it was reported that another physician operated and cut a large amount of "vaginal skin" and mesh. The patient now reports pain from the device.

Patient underwent umbilical hernia repair where Proceed Ventral Patch was used. Patient experienced post operative wound infection and hernia recurrence requiring further surgery at the following year.
The mesh was implanted. Post surgery patient experienced pain. Approximately 8 months after the surgery adhesions were identified on the mesh. Surgeon removed adhesions, mesh remains implanted.

The mesh didn't fix the prolapse and caused all the following:

Chronic pain, discomfort, pelvic tissue/organ erosion, chronic inflammation, inability to walk properly and be physically active, inability to have sex or sex without discomfort or pain, postural problems, recurrance of bladder prolapse, tender vaginal scars, fatigue, stress, depression, anger issues, anxiety, weight gain, loss of income, relationship breakdown, inability to perfom my role in daily life, inability to work, inability to live the life that I planned or was previously capable of, still need more correction surgeries.

Mesh inserted for anterior repair of vagina and prolapse of the uterus. Repair vault suspension/cystoscopy.

Abdominal pain, nausea, dizziness, malaise pain on bending. Acute awareness of foreign body in vagina and in the bowel region.

Returned to surgeon. Further surgery performed - posterior vaginal repair (vaginal prolapse and uterine prolapse). Symptoms persisted with worsening of bladder control, stress incontinence.

Further surgery - mesh removed.

Further surgery - repair and restructure vaginal wall.

It was reported that the patient was implanted with an Uphold Vaginal Support System during an anterior repair procedure.

Post-procedure, the patient experienced hydronephrosis, and a stent was placed in her right ureter.

It was reported that an Uphold Vaginal Support System was implanted.

Within three months of the implantation, the patient presented with a small amount of mesh exposure at the vaginal vault.

It was reported that an Uphold Vaginal Support System was implanted.

Within three months of the implantation, the patient presented with a small amount of mesh exposure at the vaginal midline.

It was reported that an Uphold Vaginal Support System was implanted.

Within three months of the implantation, the patient presented with a small amount of mesh exposure at the vaginal midline.

Patient reported that patient was implanted with a CK mesh to repair an inguinal hernia. The surgeon who performed the procedure has retired. Patient say another surgeon who performed a CT scan which showed the mesh to be fractured. Patient says that their doctor discussed their case with Dr. at a meeting in the USA. Patient claims Dr. told their surgeon of issues that have been associated with the CK Mesh. Patients surgeon performed a partial explant of the mesh (85%). The surgeon told patient that the ring had fractured and the mesh had hardened and broken apart. They used a stomach wall to repair the site. They provided the patient with a portion of the mesh. There was a portion of mesh (15%) adhered to the femoral artery. The surgeon told patient that patient would need another surgery to have a vascular surgeon remove the rest of the device. A year later, having recuperated from the revision procedure patient had a vascular surgeon explant of remaining mesh (15%).

The patient developed a large area of erosion due to vaginal mesh surgery. The mesh was used for repair of the pelvic floor. The patient suffered bleeding and pelvic pain from this "large area" of mesh erosion to the extent that walking aggravates the pain, limiting activity.
It was reported that during an Elevate Anterior implant procedure to treat for prolapse, the tip of the anterior needle broke off while attempting to insert the anterior mesh anchors.
I had reconstructive surgery for prolapse. During this surgery a sling mesh (Gynecare Prolift +M*) was used to address prolapse of the anterior wall.

It was reported that a Perigee mesh device was implanted to treat for anterior repair of the vagina and prolapse of the uterus. The Patient also underwent repair of vault suspension and cystoscopy at the same surgical procedure. Information provided indicates the Patient experienced pain, nausea, dizziness, malaise, pain on bending, and acute awareness of foreign body in the vagina and bowel region sometime after the initial implant procedure. Approx 5 months later, further surgery was performed for posterior vaginal repair (vaginal prolapse and uterine prolapse). It is indicated the Patient continued to experience symptoms listed above as well as worsening bladder control and stress incontinence. Surgery was performed to remove the mesh. Surgery was performed to repair and restructure the vaginal wall.

It was reported that the patient was implanted with a Pinnacle Anterior/Apical Pelvic Floor Repair Kit. During a follow-up appointment 6 weeks post-procedure, the physician noted that the patient had apparently “rejected” the mesh, as there was some slight vaginal bleeding and none of the mesh seemed to adhere to the vaginal tissue.
Mesh implanted, six months post-op patient presented to surgeon with redness at umbilicus, 1.5ml of pus aspirated and cultured with no growth.

An Obtryx Halo Single System Device was implanted using a horizontal incision on an unknown date approximately two years ago.

The patient reported that they have felt discomfort (specifics unknown) since the implant procedure. The physician discovered visible sub-urethral mesh erosion and dehiscence at the site of implantation.

Doctor reported he has been using V patches for his umbilical repairs for some time now. He reported an infection arise in a young patient over the last two weeks. The patient was treated in hospital, had the procedure done, went home on the same day and then two days later rang the doctor as he had "signs of an infection". The signs included redness, seroma formation and discomfort.
The patient experienced an unknown injury.

Patient underwent incisional hernia repair where Physiomesh was implanted. At the next day, patient complained of lump on right hand side. Patient was returned to theatre where it was found that mesh had become loose. Mesh was removed and another, larger, piece of Physiomesh implanted. One day later, patient complained of lump on left hand side and was returned to theatre. At operation it was found that the mesh had ripped.
Patient developed bowel obstruction one week after implantation of Physiomesh for repair of abdominal hernia requiring further surgery to relieve bowel obstruction and adhesions.

8 months after implantation of one mesh product the patient underwent further surgery where VyPro II mesh & Gynemesh was implanted. Patient has experienced pain and mesh erosion following implantation resulting in multiple revision surgeries.
Patient has experienced pain and mesh erosion.
Multiple revision surgery due to pain and mesh erosion.

It was reported that during implant of an Elevate Anterior graft the mesh fixating arm was placed firmly into the right sacrospinous ligament. Upon placing the locking eyelet of the graft onto the arm, the apical fixation arm detached "very easily, with only a light pull." The eyelet had not been locked into the mesh. The locking eyelet could not be found and the body of the mesh was not attached to the arm and it could not be retrieved.

It was reported that an Uphold Vaginal Support System was used during an anterior prolapse repair. The initial procedure was 6 to 12 months ago. The procedure was completed with this device. According to the complainant, the patient had a small mesh exposure in the vagina.

It was reported that during implant of an Elevate Anterior graft "button hole" occurred during placement of the arms. The patient reported "post operative pain" and was taken back to surgery to have the hole closed.
Patient had mesh implanted to repair para-umbilical hernia. Device did not integrate appropriately on parietal side and adhesions had developed on visceral side.

Patient underwent a surgical procedure where Prolift mesh was implanted. Patient has experienced pain, erosion, infection, urinary/bowel problems, organ perforation, fistuale, bleeding, recurrence, dyspareunia, neuromuscular problems and vaginal scarring.

Six pieces of Endoscopic GORE SEAMGUARD® Bioabsorbable Staple Line Reinforcement were implanted. The patient had immediate post op hypertension. 6 hours post op the patient was thought to have some degree of bleeding. The patient became unstable and then stabilized, but at 15 hours post op the patient needed revisonal surgery to stop the bleeding. During the revision procedure the Dr observed bleeding at the 5th firing out of 6 firings near the cardio esophageal junction of the stomach. The patient lost 3.5 –4 liters of blood and required a blood transfusion.

Patient developed recurrence of abdominal incisional hernia requiring further surgery. Original hernia repair where Ultrapro mesh was inserted; at revision surgery, mesh was found to be torn down the middle.

Patient implanted with TiMESH, however, the reported device lot# advised on hospital purchase order does not
correlate to any imported saleable stock. We are currently investigating the providence of this stock.

It was reported to sponsor that an Obtryx II, Halo was used during a mid-urethral sling procedure .
According to the complainant, during the procedure, the trocar passed through the vaginal incision and then perforated the vaginal epithelium.
Patient had a repair of an umbilical and incisional hernia using 1 x 31201 and 1 x 31202. V-Patch at incisional hernia site (Left side near inguinal area) formed a lump and mesh fibrosis.
The implant mesh had holes in the mesh from tearing.
Ventralex mesh 4.3 cm size was defective manufactured incorrectly. The concentric rings of mesh were off-centre.
A very small right-sided para-urethral sulcus with mesh exposed into the vagina.

It was reported that a PFR Kit - Pinnacle, Anterior Apical was used during an Anterior Vaginal Repair with Mesh. 4 weeks following the device implantation, the patient developed mesh erosion. It was also noticed that there was very little to no tissue ingrowth of the mesh. The patient also had viral shingles during the 4- week period post implantation.

It was reported that an Uphold LITE with Capio SLIM was used during an Anterior repair with mesh procedure.
According to the complainant, post implantation, the patient developed mesh erosion.

It was reported that an Uphold LITE with Capio SLIM was used during an Anterior repair with mesh procedure.
According to the complainant, post implantation, the patient developed mesh erosion.
A Pinnacle Pelvic Floor Repair Kit was used during a posterior prolapse repair procedure. According to the complainant a small rectal erosion occurred post operatively.

Patient presented, with 2 years of urge incontinence and recurrent urinary tract infections, having had a mesh anterior prolapse repair 6 years ago, using a Total Prolift implant. Examination revealed an anterior vaginal mesh erosion 4 x 0.5 cm at vault vagina. Cystoscopy revealed 1 cm supratrigonal bladder mesh erosion just to right of midline.
Thread removed from reinforcement material.

It was reported "The patient had a hernia recurrence. When the procedure began, it was discovered that the mesh, had contracted and had bowel adhesions. The recurrence was at the same location. The contracted mesh and adhesions were an incidental finding during the revision procedure but it was necessary to remove the adhesions and mesh in order to repair and reduce the hernia to ensure a successful outcome for the patient."
Mesh migration into vaginal wall - Chronic Severe Pain in vagina, anus, perineum and pelvic musculature.
CQUR Mesh implanted. Patient admitted for repair of recurrent large ventral hernia.
V-Patch implanted in March 2014. Patient complained of ongoing pain and discharge from the umbilicus and it was reported to the surgeon that a part of the mesh was protruding from the skin.

The Pinnacle device was implanted. After the surgery, the patient became totally incontinent and a few days after surgery, the patient developed an infected hematoma. Dr removed the central portion and evacuated the hematoma. The incontinence worsened. The patient was wet day and night.
It was reported that an Uphold mesh was implanted and the device caused pain and discomfort. Also, the patient developed erosion post implantation.
I have removed 3 meshes from patients with complications, including chronic pain, severe scarring, overactive bladder syndrome and restricted pelvic floor muscle movement.
I have removed 4 meshes from patients with complications, including chronic pain, severe scarring, overactive bladder syndrome and restricted pelvic floor muscle movement.
I have removed 2 meshes from patients with complications, including chronic pain, severe scarring, overactive bladder syndrome and restricted pelvic floor muscle movement.

I have removed 2 meshes from patients with complications, including chronic pain, severe scarring, overactive bladder syndrome and restricted pelvic floor muscle movement.
Patient underwent an umbilical hernia repair where Proceed Ventral Patch was inserted. Patient was diagnosed with a hernia recurrence 5 months later and requiring further surgery.

It was reported that a Pinnacle device was implanted and, after the procedure the patient became incontinent and developed infection and erosion. The central part of the mesh was excised but the patient was still incontinent.
This patient had excising breast implants and developed breast cancer and had mastectomy via an infra-mammary incision and insertion of another implant which was about 100g larger.
Dr reported issue with CQUR Mesh. Said he explanted mesh as it had 50% shrinkage.
Dr reported that he had a patient that claimed that they had an allergic reaction to the O3FA.

8 weeks post-op Dr noticed a greyish discoloration take place midline through the breast. After taking pt back to theatre & debriding the area, he saw no sign of infection, excised the area & closed, only to notice it occur again a couple of weeks later.
Patient has experienced post-operative hernia recurrence.

A leak from the gastric bypass procedure was found and there was pus around the device from the leak. It was reported by the surgeon that the device was explanted due to infection one week after implant.

It was reported that the patient was implanted with a Bard/Davol mesh. After 5 months, the patient complained of pain but the CT Scan was normal. A year later, the patient's incision site started to leak the surgeon drained a subcutaneous abscess.
Following the implantation of a Miniarc Precise the patient experienced pelvic pain. It was also reported that the patient had "developed faecal incontinence".

It was reported that a large male patient had a Ventrio ST placed 2 weeks ago and has now had a recurrence. The doctor has suggested that due to the Seprafilm, the slippery finish of the mesh once hydrated has caused it to move around inside the patient.
Meshed removed due to post op complications.
According to the complainant, the patient experienced pain. Upon examination, mesh was noted within the bladder.
During the firing of the Capio device, the tiny titanium bullet on the end of the suture was pulled-off.

Mesh implanted 11 years ago, multiple erosions of mesh through side of Vagina, requiring surgical intervention as well as many surgical "snips" as called by doctor.
Partial removal of mesh 5 years ago, further surgical intervention for mesh erosion by doctor 4 years ago and 3 years ago.
Cystoscopy for further mesh erosion 2 years ago.
Mesh removed 2 months ago for mesh erosion and mesh embedded in bladder and bowel.
A week after implantation of the mesh, I suffered pain in the pelvic region, painful sex, incontinence with the bowel and bladder, cannot lift or stand and sit for any length of time.
Have had pelvic pain, pain with sex incontinence with bowel and bladder, cannot sit, walk, stand on feet for extended time.

Immediately following surgery, nerve pain symptoms developed. Burning sensation and pain in my vagina and urethra.
Faecal and bladder incontinence, as well as painful sex.
I developed paraesthesia in my left leg down to my toes as well as sciatic pain.
Severe increase in anxiety.

Twenty days after Monarc was implanted for incontinence patient presented to the closest emergency with migraine like symptoms and a sudden inability to stand and walk. Patient continued to have internal infections, abdominal pain, bloating, bowel and bladder pain/bleeding and voiding/motion difficulties and hospitalisations. Incontinence returned and with it came verve pain and dyspareunia. Sort treatment from implanting surgeon and other doctors to identify source of problems.
Following procedure patient has experienced ongoing pain and has difficulty walking.
Patient underwent a parastomal hernia repair including placement of Physiomesh. Patient represented eight months post-operatively with visible hernia recurrence.
Patient represented with hernia recurrence.
As the mesh was being inserted via the introducer the blue sleeve covering the introducer kept bunching up, making it very difficult for the mesh to be inserted.

This device caused intractable right hip pain, frequent recurrent urinary tract infections and sexual dysfunction. It then eroded into my vagina. Developed intractable pain, recurrent incontinence and bowel dysfunction.
Patient had Left Skin Sparing mastectomy (SSM), nipple sacrificing with Mentor tissue expander 350cc and Veritas 12x25 implanted. Later, patient developed seroma.

Product has integrated, with natural tissue causing all pelvic tissue to become necrotic as well as persistent infections followed by skin changes and loss of balance, general malaise continuing with pain intensity.
Vaginal mesh erosion causing bleeding.
Pain over the mesh site with intercourse and ongoing urinary incontinence symptoms.
During the procedure, the physician perforated the bladder with the mesh. This mesh was removed from the patient, but blue mesh fibers were noticed floating in the bladder after removal of the mesh.

Monarc sling inserted for stress urinary incontinence. Post op complications were inability to void, extreme pelvic pain, ongoing urinary tract infections, vaginal infections, complete transverse erosion through urethra, chronic pelvic pain, voiding dysfunction, extreme pain during intercourse, mesh extrusion, muscular pelvic pain, atypical vaginal discharge, recurrence of incontinence, urinary frequency, atypical vaginal discharges, depression, mesh close to vaginal wall surface in 3 places, swelling around urethra, contracture barbed wire pain, increased prolapse, adhesion formation, constipation defacation dysfunction, joint pain.

The sling had to be removed due to a multitude of reasons, including but not limited to, erosion and disintegration into my urethra and surrounding tissue, infection, urine leakage, incontinence, pain during intercourse, hip, groin, abdominal and leg pain, abscesses amongst others.
Monarc sling inserted 1.5 years ago. Found to have eroded through vaginal wall post surgery.
After patient's monarc sling was found to have eroded, it was cut, however continued to cause issues & incontinence and was partially removed. Sections remain insitu and cause pain.
Mesher cut graft incorrectly and another graft got stuck.
Pain due to mesh erosion and recurrent vaginal prolapse of anterior vaginal wall.

Upon removal of the Echo PS Balloon from the patient through the port, the balloon broke apart at one junction. Internal components were then freed from the balloon and also had to be removed from the abdomen.
Patient had undergone implantation of mesh for a large direct inguinal hernia. Patient has currently presented with a recurrence.
Implanted with 'mesh' 9 years ago for a vaginal vault prolapse - Abdominal & lower back discomfort & post coital bleeding

Vaginal pain, pain with intercourse, tape exposure, muscular groin pain, leg pain, nerve pain, lower back pain, pelvic pain, foreign material in vagina, mild chronic inflamation, possible foreign body reaction, related pyschological pain and pyschological conditions. Unable to sit, stand or walk for long periods.
SPARC mesh tape has eroded into urethra, causing damage to a large area of tissue as well as a large defect.

I had surgery for a uterine, bladder and bowel prolapse and Gynecare Gynemesh PS, a urogynaecological mesh inserted and Gynecare TVT sling inserted (trans-vaginal tape). Since the operation I have constant chronic pain. The mesh has extruded into vagina.

Patient was implanted with “gynemesh” 4 years ago. Patient has been in and out of surgeries since implantation. Mesh has caused debilitating effects on her life. Patient has another surgery scheduled.
17 months after the bladder sling surgery, stress incontinence recurred and urge incontinence commenced.
The hernia surgery failed. An imaging report received indicated no change in the hernia in 4 years.
Intercourse has been non existent since the installation of this device because of pain. I also suffer with pain daily in my lower core and knees and nerve pain all over my body.

Searing pain in the top of my right leg and couldn't move leg for 48 hours post surgery. Mesh erosion through skin. Second surgery which worsened condition. Now has pudendal neuralgia which is damage to the pudendal nerve and further mesh erosion. I also have depression.

Pain Symptoms
- Pain with sitting, standing, walking
- Pain in coccyx, tailbone
- Pain lower back
- Rectal and perineum pain like a pestle is inside pressing
- Genital numbness and tingling
- If constipated magnifies pain
- Depression
- Can only be active for a few hours
- Vulva area bright red
- Pain throbs if sitting too long and or standing
- More sensitive to stress
- Full feeling in pelvis, abdomen
- Pain in right leg, when laying cannot lay my leg out to the right, muscle grabs, restricted movement
Eroded Gynemesh mesh was partially removed after it had lacerated the vaginal vault.

Constant problems since the mesh was inserted. Patient has suffered from vaginal pain, tearing and bleeding. They are unable to have sex due to pain and vaginal shrinking, diagnosed with autoimmune problems, pain in hips, knees and ankles, fluid retention. Multiple urinary tract infections and they suffer depression, stress and anxiety.

Severe unexplainable UTI'S, right hip pain unable to lay on right side, cannot lay on back, aching pelvis, frequent need to urinate but cannot go, weight gain and bloating, cannot stand too long, legs ache, painful uncomfortable sex.

Patient had mesh insert Patient unable to void urine properly since surgery. Pain developed in pelvis, hips and left leg. Sharp stabbing pain whenever bowel or bladder was full. Strong ache developed within 6 months around coccyx which stopped patient from sitting comfortably on chairs. Patient on pain relief every day since the mesh was implanted.
Mesh exposure, recurring prolapse, mesh erosion, pain and infections, pain during sex, vaginal scaring, urinary problems, problems with my bowel.

Constant Backache, Foreign object feeling in rectum. Right hand side (from under rib cage to groin) always tightness. Pain around sacrum
Discomfort & stiffness all around pelvis, but more so RHS ,Lethargy, General feeling of unwell, Left leg uncomfortable sometimes.
Nerve pain in groin. Chronic pain. Foreign body response. Alopacia areata. Anxiety. Cannot walk far. Nausea. Tiredness - Fatigue. UTI + urge incontinence.
Mesh implant has caused problems from the time of insertion. The problems have been pelvic, vaginal and abdominal pain, dyspareunia, erosion into vaginal wall, vaginal discharge.
An Uphold LITE Vaginal Support System was used during a pelvic floor repair procedure. During the procedure, 4mm of the Capio carrier detached and was left inside the patient.

Erosion into vagina after being implanted for six weeks.
2 revision surgeries.
Pain that won't go away.
Device made no difference to incontinence.

Patient underwent a Laparoscopic Incisional Hernia Repair using Parietex mesh. A Secure Strap (Ethicon Device) and sutures embedded in mesh Parietex Composite mesh were used for fixation. Post-op, the patient went home, and approximately 24 hours after surgery, reported vomiting, a feeling of fullness, and pain. Patient was readmitted to hospital, and underwent an additional operation. When patient was readmitted for post op surgery, the bowel had protruded through the center of the mesh. Due to the bowel sticking to the mesh, injury was caused to the small bowel. It did not fistulate.

12 years ago - mesh eroded through the vaginal walls, resulting in vaginal bleeding and pain. Unable to have sex due to mesh erosion.
9 years ago - surgery was required for significant mesh ulcerations.
8 years ago - diagnosed with nerve damage (peripheral neuropathy) and hypothyroidism.
6 years ago - diagnosed with osteoarthritis.
5 years ago - diagnosed with chronic systemic reaction to the mesh due to infection and inflammation and referred for immediate removal.

As a result of the adverse outcome I have
1) Recurrence of urinary incontinence
2) Pain in the left groin
3) Developed peripheral neuropathy and right big toe is nearly completely numb
4) Depression requiring medication
Constant pain, incontinence, dyspareunia, emotional stress, bulging between the vagina and anus resulting in bowel issues.

Bloating and constipation daily there are days they cannot move, they just have to lay still, constant pain daily and its only the degree of pain that varies.
Patient cannot stand for long, they cannot walk long distances, it feels like something is pulling them back, and something sticking into their back, their left leg goes numb and 3yrs ago broke their foot when they got up of the couch as they could not feel my foot, they toss and turn all night as they cannot get comfortable, and they cannot bend down.
Development of severe pain in pelvic floor region increasing over time.
The device was implanted in the patient and almost immediately felt extreme pain on the right side of my pelvis and abdomen. Pain persisted and patient was operated on again. Pain continues.

Patient had no sensation when they wanted to pass a bowel motion. Patient could not hold onto a loose bowel motion. Patient found blood and staining on their underwear. Patient started having dreadful continual pain in her buttocks, pelvic area, groin and down her legs.

3 operations to cut off exposed mesh growing through vaginal wall. Rectum has prolapsed again. Constant heaviness and pain, Constant infections, vaginosis, vaginitis, unexplained bacterial infections, constant bad smell.
It was reported that the pig tail (a connector) came off the balloon as it was being extracted through a 15mm port.
Mesh eroded through vagina, lots of pain.

Incontinent shorty after the mesh was put in. Mesh caught on one side in the patient's obtulator nerves. Ongoing problems of UTI, infections, burning pain, urinary tract obstruction, voiding difficulties and urethra is now rigid and goes to the right, urge incontinence, stress incontinence and pain during sex. Pressure and pain in rectum area and when sitting down. Adhesions allergic reaction, constipation. Constant pain, and very emotionally scarred.
Mesh was used for this anterior vaginal repair. 2 instances of significant bleeding in the last 2 years.
Erosion into vagina, pain in lower back, right leg, another bladder prolapse through the mesh, extreme vaginal pain and bleeding and now have irritable bladder.

Pain in left groin area, left hip and abdomen, numb areas around left hip, knee and cramps in left calf muscle. Lower back pain. Pain during intercourse. Reoccurring UTI infections. Constipation. Retaining urine after voiding. Urgency to urinate. Prolapse into vagina. Sharp vaginal pains.

A multitude of problems, no sex since approx 8 weeks after implant, urinary incontinence, pain in groin, trouble walking, nerve pain down legs, cannot defecate completely without help, urge incontinence, dry mouth and eyes, developed crohnes disease in first stages, and also possible rhuematoid arthritis. Wake in the night with dead arms and tingling inability to make a fist. Cannot grip very well, up all night to urinate.
When using the mesh, the healthcare professional placed it the pre-peritoneal space and has not removed the echo positioning system.

Erosion Through Vaginal Wall - Back pain - Stomach Pain - Vaginal Pain - Pain in Legs & Groin Area - Urinary Tract Infections.
Constant Infections.

Erosion - Infection - Fevers - Low Back, Stomach, Leg & Groin Pain - Fatigue - Headaches - Difficulty in walking & sitting - Urinary Tract Infections - Difficulty in voiding - General feeling of unwellness - painful intercourse.
Since mesh implantation, patient has felt constant pain.

Complications began four months after implantation. Ache and very painful during sexual intercourse. I have headaches most days and over the last fourteen months I have experienced pelvic and lower back pain; numb hands and feet, extreme pain in the urethra; pain in the shoulder blade on my right; fluid retention on the right side of my pubic area and nausea and at times lack of appetite.
Intermittent rectal, buttock abdominal pain since insertion. Have had constant abdominal pain for a year, a number of episodes of cystitis, and have been unable to have intercourse since insertion.
Prolapse of the uterus, front and back walls of the vagina. Mesh pain syndrome - most painful areas the right side of both posterior and anterior Prosima meshes.

Painful intercourse, Mild incontinence, Pelvic Pain, spasms in vagina with pins/needles, Buttock pain, unexplained fainting episodes, Lichen sclerosus, skin on arms, upper legs itchy, Polyp in vagina, and in uterus.

Since these mesh insertions, patients life has been impacted seriously. No longer able to have intercourse due to severe pain. Suffered erosion of vaginal mesh which required vaginal vault mesh exposure excision and oversewing surgery. General pain within the vagina and surrounding tissues is now constant.
Constant pain. Device didn't remain in correct place on implantation.
Incontinence. Caused increasing pelvic pain, fatigue, muscle weakness & nerve pain. Implant not holding up anything and arms not attached to muscle but waving free.

Mesh Exposure, acute pain, voiding dysfunction, pain during intercourse, recurrence of incontinence, urge incontinence, urinary frequency, feelings of cystitis, urinary retention, exposed mesh caused scratching, pain, constipation/defecation dysfunction, impossible to indulge in sexual intercourse, Lichan Sclerosus and total loss of architecture of the vaginal area.

Pain. Dragging feeling as if vagina is an open wound. Groin pain, pain behind knees, buttocks, inside legs and down front of legs. Pelvic bones feel like they've been bashed. UTIs. Pain. Erosion into vaginal wall in 3 places. Many other problems like feeling weak all the time. Body sore to touch. Many UTIs had to go on 7 months of antibiotics straight.

Painful tugging and stabbing sensations in vagina, groin and lower abdomen. Sexual intercourse painful and sometimes impossible. Bouts of rashes around lower abdominal area. Problems with voiding and defecation. Various doctors diagnosed me with fibromyalgia and arthritis. Deep aching pains in hips, lower back and coccyx.
